entry.title: Encoding Physics to Learn Reaction-diffiusion Processes
entry.content:
Abstract

A novel deep learning framework that forcibly encodes/preserves given physics structure to facilitate the learning of the spatiotemporal dynamics in sparse data regimes.

  • forward and inverse analysis of PDE systems
  • data-driven modeling
  • discovery of governing PDEs

Introduction

problems

  • laws of many systems remain uncertain or partially unknown
  • the computational cost of accurate numerical simulation is also prohibitive
  • the pure data-driven methods encounter the generalization issuse
  • the dominant physics-informed learning model generally represents a continuous learning paradigm
  • the discrete learning models, such as CNNs, GNNs and transformers alse have their disadvantages (a rich set of labeled data or given the explicit PDEs)

the proposed physics-encoded model

  1. discrete, hard encodes the physics structure into network architecture
  2. employs a unique convolutional network to capture the spatial patterns while time marching is performed by the recurrent unit
  3. incorporate well-known numerical time integration methods

Results

Physics-encoded Spatiotemporal Learning

The motivation is to establish a generalizable and robust model for predicting the physical system state based on very limited low-resolution and noisy measurement data. The established model is expected to deliver good extrapolation capability over the temporal horizon and generalization to difffferent ICs.

the state variable is updated by a recurrent network given by

the propose network, i.e. PeRCNN, consists of two major components: a fully Conv as initial state generator (ISG) and used for recurrent computation.

ISG is introduced to produce the high-resolution initial state in the case that only low-resolution initial state (or measurement) is available as initial condition.

Mathematically, the given by

Physics-encoded

  • encode these terms into network by the physics-based FD Conv connection, better than physics-informed learning model for the capbility to leverage the incomplete PDE. (can accelerate the training speed and improve the model inference accuracy significantly)
  • encode the boundary conditions (e.g. Dirichlet or Neumann type) into learning model by the physics-based padding

Reaction-diffusion systems

General RD system can be described by

the RD system is governed by

the FN RD system can be described by

the GS RD system can be described by

Forward analysis of PDE systems

The governing PDEs and I/BCs are completely known. The prescribed initial state is fed to the network for the recurrent computation without resorting to ISG.

compare the performance of the PeRCNN with ConvLTSM and PINN in 2D , 2D/3D FN and 2D GS RD equations.

Inverse analysis of PDE Systems

consider the 2D GS RD system governed by

with unknown coefficients.

Scenario 1: multiple noisy and low-resolution snapshots;

Scenario 2: only the first and last snapshots with decent resolution. The two scenarios reflect the trade-off between the spatial and temporal resolution.

Data-driven Modeling of Spatiotemporal Dynamics

Assuming some low-resolution and potentially noisy snapshots of the system are measured, they seek to establish a predictive model that gives the most likely high-resolution solution.

2D GS RD equation. the resolution of measurement data is relatively low in space but decent in time: 41 nosiy snapshots of a 26*26 grid, ranging from t=0 400 s. Assuming the scalar coefficients of PDE's diffusion term are unknown, they encode the diffusion term into PeRCNN by creating a physics-based FD Conv connection with the discrete Laplace operator. Each model is responsible for predicting 801 fine-resolution snapshots for the training phrase, 1700 snapshots for extrapolation.

3D GS RD equation. The training data includes 21 noisy low-resolution snapshots (25^3) uniformly sampled from t = 0 ~ 150 s. The piror knowledge and the estimation of the diffusion coefficients in the 2D GS RD example are adopted here. Each trained model produces 301 high-resolution (49^3 ) snapshots during the learning stage, while 700 extrapolation steps are predicted.

Generalization to different ICs. They employ the above trained model to performi inference with a different IC.

Data-driven Discovery of PDEs Scarce and Noisy Data

They extend the proposed model for discovering the closed-form governing PDEs and integrate the sparse regression technique with their model for solving this problem.

If the column space of the library matrix is sufficiently rich, the governing PDE of the system can then be written as a linear system, namely

Iterative search with STRidge can be performed to find the optimal tolerance

PeRCNN is used to reconstruct the high-fifidelity solution, which is subsequently used for computing the partial derivative terms involved in the library.

Data Reconstruction. The data reconstruction step is first performed with the help of PeRCNN as a high-resolution data-driven predictive model, just like the previous section of Data-driven Modeling.

Sparse Regression. Collect the candidate set from the network for data reconstruction by performing symbolic computations on the and establish the library matrix . Then sparse regression is performed to find a suitable coefficient vector by the STRidge algorithm. (The reconstructed data is downsampled to avoid the very large number of rows.)

Fine-tunning of coefficients.

To fully exploit the available measurement and further improve the accuracy of the discovered equations, we introduce the coefficient fine-tuning step to produce the final explicit PDE formula. The rest of training procedure is the same as that discussed in Inverse Analysis of PDE Systems:

Interpretability of the learned model

In the 3D GS RD case in Data-driven Modeling, the parallel Conv layers in have the fifilter size of 1, which implies that each output channel is the linear combination of u, v and a constant. With the element-wise product operation among three Conv layers, a third degree polynomial will be produced to account for the reaction term of the system. Then, and are got.

To interpret terms involving partial derivatives, we could completely freeze or impose moment matrix constraints on part of the convolutional filters.

The selection of difffferential operators to be embedded is crucial for identifying the genuine form of the

Discussion

Methods

Motivation of the network architecture design

The motivation of

  1. the nonlinear activation function is a source of poor interpretability.
  2. the elementwise product operation makes a better approximation in the form of multivariate polynomial.
  3. the block is flexible at generalizing the nonlinear function by choosing the size of parallel layers.

The acts as an universal polynomial approximator to unknown nonlinear function while the physics-based Conv layer accounts for the prior knowledge on the governing equation.

Universal polynomial approximation property for

  • proof 1
  • proof 2

Loss functions

When the full knowledge are available, the physics residual is employed as loss function

In the problem of data-driven modeling, the goal is to reconstruct the most likely full-field solution given some low-resolution snapshots
entry.summary: A novel deep learning framework that forcibly encodes/preserves given physics structure to facilitate the learning of the spatiotemporal dynamics in sparse data regimes.

entry.title: Understanding Convolutions on Graphs
entry.summary: Neural networks traditionally used to operate on fixed-size or regular-structured inputs are unable to elegantly process graph-structured data. Graph neural networks (GNN) are a family of neural networks that can operate natually on graph-structured data.

entry.title: A Gentle Introduction to Graph Neural Networks
entry.content:
There are many practical applications of graph neural networks in areas such as antibactertial discovery, physics simulation, fake news detection, traffic prediction and recommendation systems. This articles explore and explains modern GNN.

What a graph is

  • vertex attributes
  • edge attributes and directions
  • global attributes

to further describe each node, egde or the entire graph, we can store information in each of these pieces of the graph (using vector).

Graph and where to find them

image as graphs: each pixel represents a node and is connected via an edge to adjacent pixels. The information stores in each node is a 3-d vector.

text as graphs: each word and character is a node and is connected via an edge to the node that follow it (a simple directed graph).

In practice, this is not usually how text and images are encoded.

molecules as graphs:it's convenient to describe this 3D object as a graph, whose nodes are atoms and edges are covalent bonds.

social network as graphs: modeling individuals as nodes and their relationships as edges.

citation networks as graphs: each paper is a node and each directed edge is a citation between one paper and another.

other examples: objects in visual scenes; variables in ML models, progamming code and math equations.

What types of problems have graph structured data

graph-level task: predict the property of en entire graph.

  • molecule
  • image classification
  • sentiment analysis of text

node-level task: predict the identity or role of each node within a graph.

  • people's role in a social network
  • image segmentation
  • determine the part of speech of a word

edge-level task: predict the relationship of each node with edges

  • image scene understanding

The challenges of using graphs in machine learning

How we will represent graphs to be compatible with neural networks.

Graphs have up to four types of information: nodes, edges, global-context and connectivity. The first three can be represented with feature matrix N and the last one with adjacency lists.

Graph Neural Networks

A GNN is an optimizable transformation on all attributes of the graph (nodes, edges, global-context) that preserves graph symmetries (permutation invariances).

the simplest GNN

learning new embeddings for nodes, edges and global-context but not use connectivity.

  • use a MLP as a GNN layer
  • respectively, input node, edges and global-context vectors, get back learned nodes, edges and global-context embedding
  • stack GNN layers together

GNN predictions by pooling information

We need collect information from edges and give them to nodes for prediction by pooling. (on final layer)

  • gather each of their embeddings and concatenate
  • aggregated, usually via sum

edge to node / node to edge / node to global

Passing messages between parts of the graph

message passing, where neighboring nodes or edges exchange information, leverage the connectivity of graphs.

  • gather all the neighboring node embeddings (messages), g
  • aggragate all messages via an aggregate function (like sum)
  • pass through an update function, usually a learned neural network

Learning edge representations

We can share information between nodes and edges within the GNN layer using message passing by pooling. We could choose whether to update node embeddings before edge embeddings, or the other way around. The order we update them is one design decision.

Adding global representations

Nodes that are far away from each other in the graph may never be able to efficiently transfer information to one another. One solution: using a master node or context vector which connected to all other nodes and edges.

GNN playground

The GNN playground allows us to see how these different components and architectures contribute to a GNN's ability to learn a real task: a graph-level prediction task with small molecular graphs.

A playground, then some experimental results of its dataset...

  • a higher numeber of parameters does correlate with higher performance
  • models with higher dimensionality tend to have better mean and lower boud performance, but not much
  • the mean performance tends to increase with the number of layers, but the best performing models have two layers
  • the performance of different aggregation operations is very close
  • the performance of different ways to message passing

Into the Weeds

some myriad knowledges relevant for GNNs...

Final thoughts

Authors' conclusion.

source: https://distill.pub/2021/gnn-intro/
